metadata.titleEn: Data products of early ice velocity field of Rayner Glacier, East Antarctica (1963.08.29-1963.10.29)
metadata.description: The data product of ice flow velocity field of Rayner Glacier in East Antarctica in 1963 based on ARGON historical remote sensing images. Using two declassified satellite images taken in 1963 with an interval of two months, the early ice flow velocity field of the Reina Glacier in eastern Antarctica is estimated by hierarchical matching based on parallax decomposition. The accuracy of the estimated velocity map can reach 70 m/year. A method for estimating the surface velocity of cooperative glaciers based on the parallax decomposition of optical stereo images. First, the image to be matched generates the core image and the pyramid of the core image; Next, the ice flow area mask is used to divide the image into ice flow area and non ice flow area for matching respectively. In addition to the normal matching steps, the ice flow area also needs to perform parallax demarcation to distinguish the impact of ice flow movement on terrain parallax. Finally, through layer by layer matching, we can get the DTM and ice flow diagram of the object side at the bottom. This data is of great significance for reconstructing the early surface morphology and ice flow velocity of Rayner Glacier in East Antarctica.
metadata.instructions:
File name: Historical ice flow velocity data of Raynder glacier is stored in Geotiff format, Rayner_ Glacier_ ARGON_ 1963.08.29_ 1963.10.29_ V.tif, Rayner_ Glacier refers to the name of glacier, ARGON refers to the data source used, 1963.08.29 and 1963.10.29 refer to the time of two images, and V refers to the ice flow speed.

Data reading method: The uploaded data is in Geotiff format and can be read by Matlab, ArcGIS, QGIS and other software.

background: Environmental issues resulting from global climate change can considerably influence human society and natural environments. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s report (IPCC, 2013), it is highly probable that the increased warming and sustained mass loss of glaciers and ice sheets would further accelerate the rate of global sea level rise. Numerous studies have been performed to investigate the change of the ice sheets, the mechanism of their interaction with the ocean and responses to global climate change. Although some early data collected by in situ measurements in the 1950s or even earlier are available, they only cover regions of a limited scale and cannot be used to support change analysis of ice sheets on a large scale. Fortunately, a remarkable data source, namely, Declassified Intelligence Satellite Photography (known as DISP), collected by a series of film-based reconnaissance satellites (KH series), including ARGON, CORONA, and LANYARD, has been made available. DISP provides a unique opportunity to research early ice sheet configurations, thus greatly extending the time period of the Antarctic surface observations. Geometric processing is required as a critical procedure to utilize these historical scanned satellite films for further scientific applications. Nonetheless, the handling of these film-based data presents a variety of challenges, such as the imperfections of the early imaging mechanisms, artifacts of the films, deformation through long-period storage, and others. Numerous related studies have managed to retrieve the image geometry of historical scanned films with the aid of additional GCPs, but it is not easy to perform the processing steps in Polar Regions where the ground control is difficult to access. Only three ARGON satellite missions (mission numbers 9034A, 9058A, and 9059A) captured the scenes of Antarctica in the 1960s. Most of the studies employed ARGON imagery by registering to other more recent data using GCPs. However, the geometric reconstruction involved was usually not extensively discussed, nor were the various distortions existing in the film-based images.
research objective: This paper proposes an improved rigorous geometric modeling method for the declassified KH-5 ARGON satellite images collected in Antarctica in 1960s.
challenges: Nonetheless, the handling of these film-based data presents a variety of challenges, such as the imperfections of the early imaging mechanisms, artifacts of the films, deformation through long-period storage, and others. Although all these works managed to obtain a planimetric accuracy of approximately 1 to 2 pixels, some essential issues were not addressed due to the lack of ancillary information such as the IO parameters, the distortion parameters of the camera lens, and the orbital parameters.
methods: The scanned film images are preprocessed beforehand to enhance the quality for further analysis. Systematic errors such as lens distortion and atmospheric refraction are also considered and corrected. A scheme is proposed to measure the ground control points for the historical images based on modern image mosaic and DEM products. The bundle adjustment results of four blocks in regions in East Antarctica present a geometric positioning accuracy of less than one nominal pixel resolution (140 m) in both horizontal and vertical directions, outperforming the published results. A regional DEM of the ice sheet that represents the topography in 1963 is then generated from the stereo ARGON images for the first time.
dataset: The ARGON satellite was equipped with a frame camera having a focal length of 76.2 mm. The dimension of each frame was 11.43 × 11.43 cm, and the ground resolution was approximately 140 m, with swath coverage of 500 × 500 km. All of the frames were digitized at 7 um resolution by the US Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science Center (EROS) Scanning Department, and hence, the corresponding Ground Sample Distance (GSD) of the digital images used in this research is approximately 33 m. Besides the ARGON frame images and the corresponding footprints, the supplement to the camera calibration report and orbit ephemeris data were also involved. Moreover, the Landsat Image Mosaic of Antarctica (LIMA) (15 m resolution) and the ASTER GDEM ver 2 were employed as the reference data to assist in the selection of GCPs and Check Points (CP) so as to validate the accuracy of the geometric modeling and DEM product generated by the ARGON images.
findings: The bundle adjustment results of four blocks in regions in East Antarctica present a geometric positioning accuracy of less than one nominal pixel resolution (140 m) in both horizontal and vertical directions, outperforming the published results. A regional DEM of the ice sheet that represents the topography in 1963 is then generated from the stereo ARGON images for the first time, the evaluation of which shows its consistency with the modern product but with great value for studying the recent change history of the ice sheet.

Definition.Question: What is 'declassified KH-5 ARGON satellite images' in the context of Antarctic ice sheet research?
Definition.Answer: Declassified KH-5 ARGON satellite images refer to historical satellite photographs taken by a series of film-based reconnaissance satellites, specifically the ARGON series, which were declassified and made available for research purposes. These images are used to study early configurations of ice sheets in Antarctica and require geometric processing to correct for imperfections and artifacts in the film.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'geometric positioning accuracy' in the context of historical satellite imagery analysis?
Definition.Answer: Geometric positioning accuracy in this context refers to the precision of the spatial location information derived from historical satellite imagery, measured against nominal pixel resolution. It indicates how accurately the processed images can represent real-world locations, with the study achieving accuracy of less than one nominal pixel resolution (140 m) in both horizontal and vertical directions.

Comparison.Question: How does the geometric modeling method for declassified KH-5 ARGON satellite images compare to other traditional remote sensing methods in terms of accuracy and challenges?
Comparison.Answer: The geometric modeling method for KH-5 ARGON images involves handling challenges such as imperfections in early imaging mechanisms and artifacts from film storage. This method achieves a geometric positioning accuracy of less than one nominal pixel resolution (140 m) in both horizontal and vertical directions, which may outperform traditional methods that do not extensively address these specific distortions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities between using ARGON historical satellite imagery and modern satellite imagery like Landsat for reconstructing ice flow velocity fields?
Comparison.Answer: ARGON historical satellite imagery provides a unique opportunity to extend the observation period back to the 1960s, offering insights into early ice sheet configurations. However, it involves handling more geometric distortions and lacks comprehensive ancillary data compared to modern satellite imagery like Landsat. Both methods require geometric processing and use ground control points for accuracy validation, but modern imagery generally offers higher resolution and more readily available IO parameters.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise from using declassified intelligence satellite photography for reconstructing historical ice sheet configurations, and how can they be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include imperfections in early imaging mechanisms, film artifacts, and deformation from long-term storage. These can be addressed by preprocessing scanned film images to enhance quality, correcting systematic errors such as lens distortion and atmospheric refraction, and employing modern image mosaics and DEM products to measure ground control points, ultimately achieving a high geometric positioning accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the integration of modern reference data, such as the Landsat Image Mosaic of Antarctica and ASTER GDEM, enhance the accuracy of geometric modeling and historical DEM products?
Interpretation.Answer: Modern reference data can be used to assist in the selection of ground control points and check points, validating the accuracy of geometric modeling and DEM products generated from historical ARGON images. This integration helps ensure that the geometric positioning accuracy is less than one nominal pixel resolution, allowing for more accurate reconstructions of historical topographies and enabling studies of recent changes in the ice sheet.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is geometric processing critical for the use of historical scanned satellite films in scientific applications?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Geometric processing is critical for the use of historical scanned satellite films in scientific applications because it is required to retrieve accurate image geometry necessary for further analysis, especially given the absence of ancillary information such as interior orientation (IO) parameters, distortion parameters of the camera lens, and orbital parameters.

Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of ground control points for historical satellite images is influenced by the availability of modern image mosaics and digital elevation models (DEMs), such as the Landsat Image Mosaic of Antarctica and the ASTER GDEM, which assist in validating the accuracy of geometric modeling and DEM products generated from historical images.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences for the accuracy of ice flow speed estimation when employing historical satellite imagery that requires geometric processing?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using historical satellite imagery, such as the ARGON images, necessitates comprehensive geometric processing to correct for various errors including lens distortion and atmospheric refraction. This processing can achieve a geometric positioning accuracy of less than one nominal pixel resolution (140 m), which is essential for generating accurate ice flow speed estimates.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using ARGON satellite imagery for constructing a regional DEM of East Antarctica in terms of historical and contemporary data integration?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating ARGON satellite imagery with contemporary data sources like LIMA and ASTER GDEM allows for the creation of a regional DEM representing 1963 topography. This integration provides valuable insights into the historical configuration of ice sheets and helps in assessing recent changes in ice sheet dynamics, offering a significant contribution to understanding long-term glacial and climate interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind utilizing declassified KH-5 ARGON satellite images for estimating early ice flow velocity fields in the East Antarctic Rayner Glacier region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to estimate the early ice flow velocity fields of the East Antarctic Rayner Glacier, taking advantage of the extended time period of the Antarctic surface observations provided by the declassified KH-5 ARGON satellite images, which offer a unique opportunity to research early ice sheet configurations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of creating a regional DEM from stereo ARGON images for understanding the historical topography of ice sheets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Creating a regional DEM from stereo ARGON images is significant because it represents the topography of ice sheets in 1963, providing valuable data for studying the recent change history of the ice sheet and validating the consistency with modern products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the procedure for estimating the early ice flow velocity fields using historical satellite imagery in East Antarctica?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves using two declassified satellite images taken two months apart in 1963. These images undergo a process of parallax decomposition for layered matching, allowing the estimation of early ice flow velocity fields. The method includes generating core images, creating image pyramids, and masking ice flow regions to separate them from non-ice flow areas. Disparity demarcation is used to distinguish ice flow movement from terrain parallax effects. The final step involves layer-by-layer matching to obtain a digital terrain model (DTM) and ice flow map.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are historical satellite film images processed to improve their quality for scientific analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The scanned film images are preprocessed to enhance their quality, which includes correcting systematic errors such as lens distortion and atmospheric refraction. Ground control points for these images are measured using modern image mosaics and DEM products. This preprocessing allows for more accurate geometric positioning, with adjustments achieving less than one nominal pixel resolution in accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to handle the challenges of geometric reconstruction of historical satellite images in polar regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Handling the challenges of geometric reconstruction involves preprocessing the images to correct for imperfections in early imaging mechanisms, film artifacts, and deformation from long-term storage. The process includes using ground control points from modern data, such as the Landsat Image Mosaic of Antarctica and the ASTER GDEM, to validate accuracy. Bundle adjustment is applied to achieve high geometric positioning accuracy, and a regional DEM is generated from stereo images to represent historical topography.

Expectation.Question: Why might geometric processing of historical scanned satellite films pose challenges for data collection in polar regions?
Expectation.Answer: Geometric processing of historical scanned satellite films can be challenging in polar regions due to imperfections in the early imaging mechanisms, artifacts of the films, deformations from long-term storage, and a lack of ancillary information such as interior orientation parameters, camera lens distortion parameters, and orbital parameters. Additionally, accessing ground control points in these remote regions is difficult, complicating the process.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for employing modern image mosaic and DEM products in the analysis of historical satellite images?
Expectation.Answer: Modern image mosaic and DEM products are used in the analysis of historical satellite images to measure ground control points and check points, which are essential for validating the accuracy of geometric modeling and DEM products generated from historical imagery. These modern references help overcome the lack of ancillary information and improve the accuracy of historical data processing.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to consider systematic errors such as lens distortion and atmospheric refraction in the preprocessing of scanned film images?
Expectation.Answer: Considering systematic errors like lens distortion and atmospheric refraction is crucial in the preprocessing of scanned film images to enhance their quality for further analysis. Correcting these errors ensures more accurate geometric modeling and improves the reliability of the derived data products, such as DEMs, which are essential for studying historical ice sheet configurations.

Judgmental.Answer: The geometric modeling method is effective as it addresses systematic errors like lens distortion and atmospheric refraction, and proposes a scheme for measuring ground control points using modern data. This approach results in a geometric positioning accuracy of less than one nominal pixel resolution (140 m), which outperforms previously published results.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges in using historical satellite imagery for generating datasets that accurately reflect early ice sheet configurations?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges include dealing with imperfections in early imaging mechanisms, artifacts from films, deformation due to long-term storage, and the lack of ancillary information such as camera lens distortion parameters and orbital parameters. Accessing ground control points in Polar Regions also adds a layer of difficulty.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges and solutions involved in preprocessing historical satellite film images for ice flow velocity estimation.
Request/Directive.Answer: Handling historical film data presents challenges such as imperfections in early imaging mechanisms, artifacts, and deformation from long-term storage. The preprocessing includes enhancing image quality, correcting systematic errors like lens distortion and atmospheric refraction, and using modern image mosaics and DEM products to measure ground control points.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methodology used in estimating the early ice flow velocity field of glaciers using declassified satellite imagery.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodology involves using stereo ARGON images to estimate early ice flow velocity. This includes a collaborative glacier surface flow velocity estimation method based on optical stereo image pair parallax decomposition. The process involves generating core images and pyramids, applying ice flow region masks, and distinguishing ice flow motion effects from terrain parallax. Layer-by-layer matching then provides the DTM and ice flow map.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of datasets and reference data used to validate geometric modeling and DEM products in early Antarctic ice sheet research.
Request/Directive.Answer: The datasets include ARGON frame images, camera calibration reports, and orbit ephemeris data. The Landsat Image Mosaic of Antarctica (LIMA) with 15 m resolution and ASTER GDEM ver 2 are used as reference data to assist in selecting ground control points and check points, validating the geometric modeling and DEM products generated by the ARGON images.
